description:
Arboricoccus pini is a species of bacteria that was isolated from the phyllosphere (the above-ground parts) of pine trees (Pinus spp.). It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium that belongs to the phylum Actinobacteria.

The cells of Arboricoccus pini are coccoid in shape, with a diameter ranging from 0.5 to 1.0 micrometers. The bacterium is capable of growing at temperatures between 10°C and 35°C, with an optimal growth temperature of around 28°C.

Arboricoccus pini is capable of utilizing a variety of carbon sources, including glucose, fructose, and sucrose, for its growth and metabolism. It is also known to produce pigments, which can range in color from yellow to orange.

The ecological role of Arboricoccus pini in the pine tree phyllosphere is not yet fully understood, but it is believed to be involved in the cycling of nutrients and potentially in the promotion of plant growth and health.
